Out-of-town drivers making it hard to walk in the neighborhood = one star.
Tourists thinking The Haight is a haven for hippies = five stars.
Tourists thinking The Haight is a haven for hippies = one star.

This neighborhood encompasses everything and anything in between, and when you average it all out, it works out to about 3.25 stars.
author: Jim S.

description:
I really don't care about the hippie factor. There are many awesome shopping options here, some cool clothing shops, some excellent restaurants and bars. You've got Golden Gate Park at the one end, and Buena Vista at the other, lots of beautiful Victorians in between. Take it for what it is today. The past is called the past for a reason. It's still a beautiful stretch today.

Oh yeah, dealing with the substance abuse burnouts and pathetic street people begging for attention and the young people who show up in San Francisco with no money and no place to stay. If that freaks you out and you can't harden yourself to this scene then probably you should avoid the Haight. The whole city is an aggressive street people mecca, not just the Haight. I think it makes it more interesting but that doesn't make it any less of a mine field. Deal with it or don't. We spoke to a few folks and once you tell them you don't want to buy any bud they just move on. One dude asked us for a cigarette, he was nice and it didn't seem like a routine so we obliged him. We had the good fortune to pass by an excellent drumming circle in the park, it was one of the best we have heard in a long time. You just never know what is going to happen so have to be open to the experience.
author: Jef B.

description: I am a neo-hippy - really into the 60s music scene and lifestyle - so this was a MUST SEE for me and I was not disappointed. The area is kind of dodgy, but it was fun to walk around and go in all the shops. Also, I was able to see all the homes that famous musicians lived in around the area - like Janis J., the Dead and Jefferson Airplane. I LOVED this area!
author: Mary M.

description:
"Iconic part of San Francisco but the actual shops are a combination of chic, shabby and whatever."

Couldn't have said it better myself, though I suppose I may suggest that it's a combination of chic, shabby, whatever, mediocrity, identity crisis, and corporate rape (that one's just for you, Ben and Jerry's, you no longer matter.)
author: Tim Y.

description:
I really want to give this place 5 stars. But I can't. Gone is the idealism of the 60s/70s/80s. Exchanged for a bunch of hybrid cars and our parents attempting to stay healthy after many years of being burnt out.

This place isn't really much of a hippy place. You'll see tourists, metro hipsters, and trustafarian gutter punks. Yeah, I am talking to you...I know you want to rebel against the "system" and not work. But I do work, I've worked for a long time, and you're not getting my change..

I know not all of them are like this. Some are just nomads, some came from abusive homes, etc. But yeah...

The rest is just the trendy SF fare. You know, it isn't cheap to live here.

Tourists suck. Ben and Jerrys is so for them.
author: Lana P.

description: Okay so this right here was the second cross street related place I was looking forward to seeing in San Francisco. I was excited to witness some 'psychedelic'  ambiance and people walking around representing peace and love. I might sound like a complete idiot, especially to those who have actually been here. I mean I liked it, but to be honest it sort of reminded me of any other street in LA. It had a bunch of graffiti, boutiques, and marijuana shops. I just didn't get that historic hippie vibe. I don't want to completely hate on it because it is still part of history, but I think the only time I'll be in the neighborhood is if I'm catching a bus in Union Square and going to the Golden Gate bridge.
author: Shanel S.

description:
Why would anyone hate the Haight/Asbury area? 

Is it they might get scared away by people hanging out in front of the stores or corners slighty inebriated need to judge it on that,but judge on the many shops that the Haight offers. This place is outstanding if you like to shop and have unique style. The fact that it may get really crowded at times might scare some away,but don't you do that. Some might say f-it because they can't find parking. Believe me  there is,just come early enough and you will find it. 

I love this nieghborhood,shops and all it has to offer. My favorite pit stop is Amoeba record stores and the funky styled shoes places.This area also has some good clothing and dining choices. Even thou I didn't like Cha-Cha Cha that much I still enjoy this area of the city. 

Nice shops,coffee,dining,ice cream,liquor and *special stores* to peep at.

Oh,must add that the homes look quite comfy too.
author: Dani D.

description: I am in LOVE with this place.  I haven't been to many places in San Francisco (think Fisherman's Wharf, Union Square... and that's about it) so coming here was a DELIGHT.  It reminded me of a crazier Melrose.  Shopping's amazing (bad for my credit card), the bars look fun and there is GREAT people watching to be done (think tattoo of giant eyes on someone's back).  I wish I wasn't in L school so I could come here more often but... I can't, so I'll come here for weekend delights.
author: Christine B.

description: I visited this area and loved it. During the day this area was great to walk around and had some super cute shopping. Bought some records, looked at dresses, got a drink at Magnolia, and a snack at Whole Foods. One thing to note, at about 6ish, all of the stores start to close and the obnoxious homeless street punks start to come out. If you're visiting, grab a bus out of the Haight before 6 (because the bus gets sketchy too). When I was trying to leave, a guy tried to sell me hash and nuggets. I didn't bother to ask him what a nugget was.
author: Amanda M.

description: This was a great time! The shops were so unique and the atmosphere was chill.  There were so many different things to enjoy. And you have to get a picture of the street sign!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Aggressive bums and tons of street kid punks who seem to love to roam the streets begging for money didn't seem to phase me. Don't mind them and if you do then you have no spine! I found tons of small boutiques and great vintage shops while perusing both lower Haight and upper Haight. My favorite one would hands down be Held Over and the old Aardvark's which is now Haight Ashbury Vintage. 
Parking does suck which we were not concerned  about because why take a car when in the city. It's far easier to just walk or use public transpiration. Tons of taxi's out and about as well.  So, note if you drive you  will be left scouring for parking and less time enjoying the bums and boutiques!
author: Christina S.

description: Frommers made the Haight sound like it was the place to be. I think because my expectations were so high, ultimately we were let down. The stores were unique and cool to see, but given the vintage wares I expected vintage prices, but most of the apparel for sale was overpriced and not worth it! That being said it was fun to sift through shops and people watch. We saw a couple drug deals, guys with signs asking for weed, and a man with gold teeth stared at me in a provocative fashion. It's an eclectic area with a lot of diversity as well as socio-economic disparity. Worth a trip, yes, but definitely did not meet the Haight hype!
author: Nicole S.

description: Its one of those areas I think I'm supposed to go to in town and the location is good. That said, if you are over say 20 there is nothing much here anymore... unless you need a cheap haircut? really I like the close by Richmond area much better
author: Mark B.

description: Haight Ashbury was quite a bit different than what I was expecting. But I suppose in hindsight it makes perfect sense as to how it looks now and how it used to be. I always had the idea that Haight Ashbury was a hippie neighborhood and it was in the 60's. Now it is mostly yuppy so that earthy vibe you may have heard about is muted quite a bit since many hippies turned into yuppies. Still it is an area of San Francisco that is worth going to and check out the cities history. I kind of felt the same way with the Castro District as well. Anyway like I said after thinking about it it makes sense since most hippies are now yuppies that some of the shops look a bit snooty that line Haight Ashbury. Same thing has happened in Boulder,CO and probably many other locations that was once designated as hippie.
author: Alden C.

description:
Haight Ashbury is a dirty, filthy, homeless infested tourist trap. Don't waste the time and effort required to get here, it's just not worth it. you won't feel safe in this city. 
 It's a shame that San Francisco has decided to let the homeless take over their tourist areas.
author: Jeff F.

description: Took my fiancée here for the first time because I knew that she would love the shops there for shopping as much as I do. The hippie style and inscense aroma throughout the streets just lets you know this area is another part of San Francisco history. If you walk the entire area, you can end up at Golden Gate Park also
author: Charley B.

description:
I almost wanna say 3.8 stars

Alot of good places to eat here apparantly though i haven't been to any of them. There's supposed to be some good pizza here from what i've heard which is nice considering there really are not great pizza places in the Tendernob where i currently live. Alot of cafes around. This place gets alot of buzz so although i was here today in pouring rain, there was still hella people. This place is pretty cool but only on ocassion because i could see it getting old really fast. It's really just alot of stores and things. Some really really cool storessssss, but still...how often are you going to just go shopping. Off the main bust road there are some really coold hidden gems *hair salons, more tattoo/piercing/art places, perfume and organic oil/incense/candel places, more produce makets and afew notable vegan places/icecream* Cool to visit everynow and then but i wouldn't say it's an awesome everyday hangout.
author: Brittainie B.

description: Everyone says Haight Ashbury is the place to shop when you go to SF.  It is, if thrifting and weed is your thing.  Other wise, i'd just skip it and go to Fairmont Street instead.  Better shopping and dining experience.
author: Jules D.

description: The spirit of the 60's may be alive and well here, but it's all for sale, cheap. And it needs a shower and a haircut, and well . . . a purpose besides selling tee shirts and bongs.
author: Erika G.

description:
why do i like it?
-toronado
-mad dog in the fog
-rosamunde's
-that bbq place
-amoeba music
-citrus club

seriously? too much good stuff on this street.  the homeless people and junkies just give it life
author: Sean L.

description:
Haha Haight Ashbury,
even when I came here the first time i instantly felt naucious around the hipster bullshit attitude here, I cannot beleive how anyone with a bit of personality and self irony would set a foot here, well...... I did and this does not happen often for me,I feel sorry for all tourists that come to San Francisco thinking that they will find any originality in this neighbourhood, it died a long time ago, all you get now is pretentious wannabes...

Once again, No offence.
author: cecilia k.

description: interesting part of history to see. lots of great and off the wall shops. however there are alot of homeless people around
author: Andrea R.

description: Where hipsters are rebellious against the standard fashion. Yet they all look the same and have the same pompous attitude. You guys arent fooling anyone. I'd say its is just as fake as the residents of LA with their plastic surgeries.
author: Alex R.

description: BEST PLACE TO SHOP IN SAN FRANCISCO. So much fun, an occasional awesome deal, super good time.
author: Emily H.

description: After getting some quick take out at a Mexican restaurant in the Haight last night, I felt the need to thank my parents who were diligent and relentless that I did my homework and become a productive member of our society and not a bum.
author: G L.

description:
Since we finally found a parking spots for me to go to kidrobot, we decided to stick around a bit longer to walk around. 

I don't know if its the gloomy weather there or because of the dirty streets. I wasn't the biggest fans of Haight Ashbury  
They do have some interesting small stores.

I guess I just like Melrose better.
author: Chow-time W.

description: Stars for being a part of history that continues to draw people to the tiny city of San Francisco.  Also, for drawing so many great and intelligent people to the city in it's hey day.  Although the neighborhood has a certain unpleasant stench at times, it is still fun to come every once in a while and enjoy the excellent shops, and some terrific food. (Check out Ploy 2 on the corner of Haight & Stanyon)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
WELCOME TO THE HAIGHT!!!

you want food?
they got food!
you want some style?
they got style! 
(or something that closely resembles it...or maybe it's just lacking class)
you want some designer toys and paraphernalia?
they got designer toys and paraphernalia!

everything i want within spitting distance. urban sprawl complete with unadulterated, corporate free (?) merchandise and all the accouterments to go with it.  

hell...they will even throw in some Harri Krishna's for shits n giggles!!!
however i could do with less third world and more metropolitan...
author: John-Michael C.

description:
Ever since I went away for college, one thing I miss about San Francisco is shopping around Haight. The shops around are definitely unique, you probably won't find a place like it... well, Telegraph is similar to half of Haight. 

The reason why I'd give it four star is because every time I decided to take the car out and happen to be near haight, I can NEVER find parking! So, I'd take the bus!
author: Lianne D.

description:
This place deserves far more credit than we're giving it. Compared to other neighborhoods, I feel like the Haight Ashbury has done a nice job of keeping the youthful vibe in its gentrification. Likewise, there's an amazing cross section of society in this neighborhood that you can't find anywhere else. 

It deserves its' hype as a local attraction even when I hate the fact that some people stomping these grounds aren't my posse, and that the stores are getting damn expensive. But when I walk these streets and browse the stores, I'm still amidst an amazing vibe.
author: Andrew C.

description: By the time I made it here damn near everything had closed up except a few eateries. The minute I got out of the car to try & get into the Dispensary I was approached 2 different times with offers of the chronic. Well I was too late for the store so I ventured up & down the block checking out the different stores and people. Not my mother's Haight-Ashbury but definitely a unique blend of culture.
author: Scott D.

description: Touristy, dirty, and run down.  An unfortunate end to a place which birthed the hippie movement in America.  If you want trinkets, records, or souvenirs, here is your place.  There are some good cheap restaurants and bars in the area.  Watch out for young people--who are strangely dressed like normal people--walk up to you in restaurants to ask if they can eat some of your food or leftovers as if this is some continuing vestige of the Haight's illustrious past.
author: Ethan B.

description: Awesome place to check out.  Very Hipstery and there are some cool boutiques.  Plus let's not forget, the RVCA store!
author: Shad B.

description: I came out here, visiting , my X took me around town. Haight & Ashbury ,is like our South Street District, with lots eateries, pubs, cute stores, tattoo parlors, used record shops-funky boutiques. My x was under impression you had to dress a certain way to hang out there*(Mind you he is coo-coo for cocoa-puffs) on anti-depressants-just wear what you like who gives a F***??!! Anyway, his loony sister came out , too-I didn't care-nice time, we ate at the local place, had their own in-house root beer-nice-not overly sweet-Grabbed a couple tanks for the gym-liked it out there . It 's quite eclectic.., all kinds of flavor & people. Great time!! Even with crazy X. LOL
author: Jenn W.

description:
The shops here aren't that great--the 2nd hand stores are the best places (wasteland, goodwill, crossroads, etc). The smoke shops are great for seeing some pretty awesome bongs.

The best is the park though--right near hippie hill, where there's often some great festivals.
author: Shauna T.

description: Iconic part of San Francisco but the actual shops are a combination of chic, shabby and whatever.
author: P G.

description: I drove through several times. Wish I had time to walk through. Lots of neat shops, interesting people and beautiful Victorian homes. There were what appeared to be a lot of homeless youth in the park but, they looked as chill as everyone else. I have heard the neighborhood is sketchy but, it looked fine to me. Maybe nighttime is different. Next visit I will make time for at least an afternoon here if not a full day.
author: Ellie S.

description: Dirty and some more dirty.  Bums and some more bums.  My wife and  I stopped by today while we were on vacation.   I'm from way down south and  have been in some pretty seedy places - juke joints all over the MS delta, bars all over New Orleans, etc... I have never been in a place like this and don't know if I ever want to come back.  My wife was pretty much acosted by 2 males right by the McDonald's... when they saw me (6'2" - 245 lbs) the bums backed off.  About 2 blocks down, we were offered 2 joints.  It's one hell of a place.  I don't think I will ever come back... unless they need some demolition work done or the police need a hand.
author: Hess R.

description:
This place is living on fumes of social relevancy - all the "hippies" around here are just dumb kids too stupid to realize their following some abstract formula of what used to be cool... Holly Hobbie dresses over flared jeans? Guatemalan jackets? Really? I don't think so. I can't believe how many young people are still begging on the street around here - it's like a third world country.

You might be tempted to come to the Haight for the Amoeba Records or for Cha Cha Cha but both places have other locations in better parts of the city. 

The only thing worse than the smell is the lack of parking.
author: Quartknee K.

description: If you're going to San Francisco, be sure to wear some flowers in your hair and make certain you dedicate half a day to Haight Ashbury. This place is where it all happened in 1967, the summer of love. After decades of neglect and bad reputation, Haight is coming back to life and is really a pleasure to visit. Walk there from Alamo Square and enjoy the most beautiful Victorian houses in San Francisco. Janis Joplin, Jefferson Airplane, Jimmy Hendrix and The Dead have lived here and you can walk past their door.
author: CasimirVessel

description:
This is my 'hood.  Yes, it can be a bit challenging at times with the homeless youth, doggie doo doo, etc. but truly independent-minded free spirits live, work and play here!

This neighborhood is home to artists, musicians, filmmakers, writers... in other words cultural creatives and bohemians of all walks.  

Occasionally, the hipster factor is at play on who you see hanging out on the street (mostly because of the vintage and boutique clothing stores).  But the hipsters alone do not define Haight street.

There are interesting happenings at Amoeba, Booksmith, Club Deluxe any given night; there are yummy spots for dinner & a drink (Alembic, Magnolia, Citrus Club, Ken Zamans, etc.) and if you aren't put off by the occasional sales pitch for "buds" then you are guaranteed an interesting counter-cultural experience in the Haight!
author: C E.

description: The five or so blocks of Haight (oddly enough pronounced "hate") street between Masonic and the park is hippy-ville. The unofficial home for San Francisco hippies and hipsters continues into Golden Gate park as just into it is an area called hippie hill. This whole area does in fact include a number of homeless people (only half of which spend their time pan handling). It's not only the people that makes this the hippie mecca but the shops. The area is full of used/vintage clothing shops, smoke shops, shops selling Tibetan crafts, tie die clothes, records, and no shortage of places to get a tattoo or a piercing. You can even go to some unique shops like Loved to Death which you could buy some bizarre and unique things (like a taxidemied squirrel dressed in Victorian garb holding a hatchet by a chair covered in bird bones- $750). There's no street in San Francisco quite like Haight so go by and check it out. Keep in mind late afternoon/early evening is probably best as all the places are closed until 11am.
author: Matt E.

description:
Haight and Ashbury is a favorite place of mine in San Francisco but this year my friends and I felt there was something missing.  It seemed less magical than past years; less shops, the vibe was weak, more homeless kids than previous years.  I couldn't help wonder if it was just me changing in my life or if this historical place had changed so much in just one year?  I could still feel the musical scene of the 60s and 70s beneath my feet and I was stoked to be there, and of course I had a great day walking around the streets.  I didn't want to believe that perhaps the dwindling economy was hurting this precious place that had made such magical music at one point, but it seemed so. 
It took me a moment to forget all the shops, the homeless people, the corporate-ness, and the economy while standing where some of the greatest musicians to grace the earth once stood, but once I was able to close my eyes I felt the vibe I was looking for.  
Go to Haight-Ashbury and love what it used to be and what it is when you shut your eyes and listen to your heart...
author: Jaimie B.

description:
I always called this place The Haight, but Haight-Ashbury works just as well :)


 For the uninitiated, Haight-Ashbury refers to the region around the intersection of Haight St. and Ashbury St., although most of the area seems to be simply on Haight St. It had a reputation for alternative / hippy lifestyles, but now is mostly a collection of fashionable clothes stores, thrift stores and cafes. Still, it's definitely worth a visit.


 Check out Ameoba music at the west end of the street
author: Alistair H.

description: Gone are the days of the hippie. Its sad. Another SF neighborhood that has become victim to Gentrification and yuppies. But the pot culture is still present. The place is very young and hip, and the occasional hippie is still around. Got to go to Golden Gate Park for the acid though. In the last few months alone it has become more upscale. It isn't the same place that legends and stories speak of.
author: San F.

description: Follow the beat or hippie trail through this district and swing by the iconic crossroads
author: moonvalley

description: fun, fun... little noise you can find good things... but some times is better off buy new.
author: B H.

description: I love to walk around the neighborhood, check out the stores and just explore. Can get annoying with all the people and crowding but very cool to check out once in awhile and a must-see for someone visiting from out of town.
author: Hanan H.

description: Lots of quirky shops, had a good time and I HATE shopping.
author: Tony R.

description: Ageing alternative area with some clothing and shoe stores. Only bright spots - super cheap shoes, Crepe Express and ripe fruit + fresh squeezed orange juice at Haight St Market. A bit grim and not charming at all. Maybe that's the point but I wouldn't go back.
author: pj n.

description:
A Place where the SPIRIT OF THE 60's IS ALIVE AND WELL.
The Immortal Spirits of Jerry Garcia and Ron"Pigpen"McKernan
Timothy Leary,Hunter S. Thompson,Ken Kesey,Chet Helms,Bill Graham
Janis Joplin,Papa John Phillips,Mama Cass and Frank Zappa.all surround you.Just wish they were all still with us and at the nearest bar
we'd go in and kill a fifth of Southern Comfort with Janis,how cool would that be.Jerry Garcia would have his own Wine Cellar.One thing I regret in life is that I wasn't a youngster during The Summer of Love back In '67
A time when you could be as naughty as you wanted,and no one would bother you about it-very unlike today,The Grateful Dead lived at 710 Ashbury,and would play free concerts in the street.1967 was a great year for music-you had Jefferson Airplane's Surrealistic Pillow and After Bathing At Baxter's,Moby Grape debut album,Janis and Big Brother-Cheap Thrills-First Grateful Dead album on Warner Bros.Records.
I wasn't even born then,my parents had just met in '67 and married a year later.I was born 7 years later in '74,but my Dad always played this great music and still is a big fan of it to this present day.That's where I learned to like it,and I listen to it quite often myself.And According to the Music Industry in 1967-SAN FRANCISCO was known as THE AMERICAN LIVERPOOL (as in Liverpool,England).Sadly,the Winterland Ballroom is no longer there,The Grateful Dead were the last band to play there before it closed in 1978,and the establishment was razed in the early 80's,A High Rise Apartment Complex now occupies where Winterland once stood.
author: Mark P.

description: I had no expectations of hippies or rockers when I first visited.  I like the neighborhood, especially for its distance to Golden Gate Park.  I took the metro here and walked to GRSF to buy a comic book.  My boyfriend bought himself a new pair of sunglasses here.  Watch out for panhandlers.
author: Ai M.

description: A great area to wander around in! I particularly enjoy the alternative shops in the area. Lots of things to look at in the shops and lots of stuff you aren't going to find just anywhere. It's a nice walk, people are friendly, and there are great places to take photos as well!
author: michelyn

description: If you can ignore the more recent, overpriced, tourist-oriented stores, you'll find a lot to love here. Though its Janis-n-Dead heyday is over, remnants of the swingin' sixties are alive and well in the Red Vic hotel, the tie-die t-shirt store, and some of the most creative, highest-turnover, pretty-cheap vintage stores ever. Plus, the street folk aren't scary like some of the city's neighborhoods after dark. They are just as likely to give you a smile and a song as they are to ask for money. As a single girl, I never feared walking here after dark because there was always some bum on the street looking out for me. There is a real sense of community and neighborhood here, and watching out for each other. Plus, it's right near the park and you can hear the drumming from Hippie Hill! Definitely my favorite neighborhood in SF.
author: Geae D.

description: Great alternative shopping street just a few minutes up the road on a trolley from the central shopping centre, Lots of hippy/ thift/smoking paraphanalia/cute and vintage shops. The vintage dresses are cheap with the conversion rate, I Could of filled a suitcase. Some of the vintage shops are a bit pricier but they've cherry picked their selection, and you can tell- most of the shops ask you to give them your bags when you enter and they put them on a shelf behind the till ( I think it's to stop thieves) I can recommend the thrift shops for absolute bargainous bargains. La Rosa was the best vintage shop, friendly staff, great items- maybe a bit expensive. The wasteland and X generation are good alternative clothes shops, I ate at Kates Kitchen and came out deliciously filled to the brim for cheap. It took us half a day to walk up one side and down the next and we only went in a handful of shops. A great day out with something for everyone!
author: Skintight_Chorltonite

description: really cool place. lots of culture and history. be careful in some parts as its quite dodgy
author: simonefrances

description: An iconic area of San Fran. Worth going - we have some great photos. We found some cheap eats too so explore.
author: mccak83
